snippet: The approach of letting James write an open letter cast Sports Illustrated more as a public-relations ally of James than as the strong journalistic standard-bearer it has been for decades.
abstract: Richard Sandomir Sports Media column scrutinizes decision by Sports Illustrated to allow LeBron James to write an open letter on his decision to return to the Cleveland Cavaliers, suggesting that it sacrificed opportunity for a comprehensive news story in order to capture a scoop; contends that choice casts magazine as a public-relations ally of James rather than the journalistic standard-bearer it has been for decades.
lead_paragraph: The approach of letting James write an open letter cast Sports Illustrated more as a public-relations ally of James than as the strong journalistic standard-bearer it has been for decades.

headline.seo: Role of Sports Illustrated in LeBron James's Announcement Raises Journalistic Questions
headline.main: Getting the Scoop, but Not Necessarily the Story
headline.print_headline: Getting the Scoop, but Not Necessarily the Story
